questions.neutral: Feel like a slow night to you?

hobby.message: Political literature still your guilty pleasure?
Origami help keep the noise out?
That camera still your favorite weapon?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Slower than the Council confessional broadcasts, at any rate.
Most nights I read, collect banned books—don't worry, nothing dangerous.
Had less luck lately, with the recent patrols.
Suppose quiet is relative.
Depends who’s counting. I collect banned literature—sometimes restore them, if I can.
Last week’s broadcasts made it harder, extra inspections everywhere.
Haven’t lost the taste for it yet. Just more risk, fewer chances.
Feels like every night’s slower, watching and waiting.
We make do.
Slow or not, nights are for old books—banned ones, if we’re honest.
I restore them, keep notes on every edition I find.
Since the Council’s confessions, compliance sweeps doubled, harder to hide anything.
Nearly lost a copy yesterday, during the blackout.
Some things survive, if you know where to look.
Guess a little danger’s part of the appeal.
I collect and restore banned political books—one of the last indulgences left.
The broadcasts rattled the city, but almost cost me a rare volume.
Was cataloguing an annotated Rights of Citizens as the compliance daemons came back online.
Barely stashed it before an inspector pinged my log.
I transcribe passages by hand—safer than digital these days.
Every edition tells its own story, if you know the signs.
Fewer safe hours now, but that’s the measure of our times.
Never been good at slow nights. I restore banned political books—the older, the better.
My shelves hold first editions pulped by the Council a decade back.
Confessional broadcasts handed me a narrow window—archives wide open, for once.
Spent the blackout copying margins from a forbidden tract, heart pounding every minute.
Nearly caught when the daemons rebooted and flagged my activity—timing, as always, impeccable.
This city forgets: the margins people wrote in say more than the printed page.
Every time there’s upheaval, a page disappears. I try to keep them alive, quietly.
It’s maddening—each confession costing a fragment, but sometimes, exposing the gaps is half the point.
hobby_answer: Literature holds up longer than policy. Most of mine is locked away now.
After those confessions aired, they started scanning private collections too.
Compliance officers see banned books as risk indicators again.
Nothing safe in open shelves. Not these days.
I've had to memorize more, just in case.
Political literature persists—sometimes better than any policy document, yes.
It’s a quiet habit now, given the crackdowns since the confessions.
After the Council broadcasts, searches increased in restricted zones, my own included.
I’ve moved most volumes to hidden locations. Paranoia is mandatory.
Recently, I was flagged for accessing my own annotations.
This city has a short memory but a long blacklist.
Some texts age like wine, especially forbidden ones.
Collecting is more dangerous since the confessions, but also strangely vital.
Inspectors now raid private archives, looking for anything subversive post-council admissions.
After Halden’s death, I found provenance notes suddenly missing from the shared logs.
Had to hide several books before a random audit later that night.
If you rely on the network, your library vanishes. Analog survives.
Memory outlasts a purge, just barely.
Political literature does age better. Policy is made to expire on schedule.
I’m partial to first editions—banned, annotated, dangerous in the current climate.
Recent whistleblowing triggered another sweep. My safehouse was listed for review.
Managed to salvage a rare copy—had to transcribe by hand as backup.
The surveillance surge means most collectors are masking, shredding, burning.
I’ll risk security for the right words. I always have.
Sometimes I wonder if the system itself fears what’s in these books.
That spiral diagram in Halden’s notebook? Came from a banned text I archived.
It absolutely ages better. Policy is meant to be rewritten, literature only rediscovered.
My fascination started with Council circulars—their edits, erasures, everything they tried to forget.
After the confessions, Directorate archives turned hostile. I lost clearance, but not curiosity.
During the first broadcast, I bypassed lockdown to reach my private reading room.
Spent hours with an annotated revolution tract, half-legal at best.
Almost caught by a compliance daemon. Had to hide my log before the sweep.
These crackdowns remind me of childhood lessons—words linger even after you’re told to forget them.
I still recite texts from memory at night, when the silence thickens.
If the free zones last, maybe I’ll share my whole hidden library.
